revision.text:
{{Expand Spanish|Ejército del Pueblo Paraguayo|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox war faction | name = Paraguayan People's Army | native_name = ''Ejército del Pueblo Paraguayo'' | native_name_lang = español | war = [[Insurgency in Paraguay|internal conflict in Paraguay]] | image = [[File:Emblema del Ejército del Pueblo Paraguayo.svg|150px]] | caption = EPP's badge{{cite news|title=EPP se burla de Cartes al ofrecer recompensa|url=http://www.ultimahora.com/epp-se-burla-cartes-ofreciendo-recompensa-y-poniendole-alias-n1064820.html|accessdate=18 July 2017|agency=Ultima Hora|language=es}}{{cite news|title=EPP admite error en secuestro de Wiebe y exige repartir víveres para liberarlo - Edicion Impresa - ABC Color|url=http://www.abc.com.py/edicion-impresa/politica/epp-admite-error-en-secuestro-de-wiebe-y-exige-repartir-viveres-para-liberarlo-1557515.html|accessdate=18 July 2017|agency=Color ABC|date=20 January 2017|language=es-ES}} | active = 1 March 2008 — present | ideology = [[Marxism-leninism]]
[[Proletarian internationalism|Internationalism]]
[[Environmentalism]] | clans = | leaders = Osvaldo Villalba
Manuel Cristaldo Mieres
Magna Meza
Carmen Villalba
Osmar Martínez †
Alcides Oviedo Brítez | headquarters = [[Horqueta]] | area = {{flag|Paraguay}} | strength = 150-200 fighters | partof = | previous = | next = | allies = {{flagicon image|Flag of the FARC-EP.svg}} [[FARC]] (Government claims)
{{flagicon image|Bandera de la ACA.svg}} [[Armed Peasant Association]] | opponents = {{flag|Paraguay}}
{{flag|Colombia}} | battles = | website = | identification_symbol = | identification_symbol_2 = [[File:Insignia del EPP.svg|center|150px]] | identification_symbol_label = Flag | identification_symbol_2_label = Banner | active2 = Active | motives = Overthrow the Paraguayan government and establish a [[socialist State]] | position = [[Far-left]] | colours = {{legend|green|Green|outline=#343434}} {{legend|red|Red|outline=#343434}} | split = | designated_as_terror_group_by = {{flag|Paraguay}} }} The '''Paraguayan People’s Army''' ({{lang-es|Ejército del Pueblo Paraguayo}}, '''EPP''') is a [[communist]]{{cite web|author=ultimahora.com |url=http://www.ultimahora.com/ejercito-paraguayo-del-pueblo-ya-incursiona-militarmente-n102273.html |title=Paraguay: Ejército Paraguayo del Pueblo ya incursiona militarmente |publisher=ultimahora.com |date= |accessdate=2014-09-02}} [[Guerrilla warfare|guerrilla]] movement that has staged a number of armed operations, including bombings, arson attacks, shootings and kidnappings as part of an organized [[Paraguayan People’s Army insurgency|insurgency]]. They operate in northern Paraguay, with most incidents occurring in [[Concepción Department (Paraguay)|Concepción Department]], as well as the neighboring departments of [[Canindeyú Department|Canindeyú]] and [[San Pedro Department, Paraguay|San Pedro]]. The EPP are believed to number 50-80 members.{{cite web|author=Infosurhoy.com |url=http://infosurhoy.com/en_GB/articles/saii/features/main/2013/11/26/feature-01 |title=Paraguay: Government increases presence to combat EPP |publisher=Infosurhoy |date= |accessdate=2014-05-19}} As of March 2012, the group was suspected of carrying out 27 separate operations, with more than half of them occurring after January 2011. These incidents resulted in the deaths of at least 16 people — 9 civilians and 7 police officers.{{cite news|last=Ramsey|first=Geoffrey|title=Tracking the Rise of Paraguay's Rebel Army|url=http://www.insightcrime.org/news-analysis/tracking-the-rise-of-paraguays-rebel-army|newspaper=In Sight Crime|date=March 6, 2012}} By December 2013, the insurgency resulted in killing of at least 33 civilians and police officers,"The EPP has now killed 33 people, including police officers and civilians, since 2005, the government said." [http://latino.foxnews.com/2013/12/08/guerrillas-kill-soldier-in-paraguay/] with an unknown number of killed EPP operatives. By mid 2016, fatalities from the insurgency had surpassed 60, most of them civilians and police. ==Origins== The EPP began as an offshoot of another radical fringe group, the Free Homeland Party ([[Partido Patria Libre]] – PPL). After the PPL was taken apart by police in 2005, several members decided to form a new group with which to continue the armed struggle.{{cite news|last=Díaz|first=Natalia Ruiz|title=Paraguay: Controversy Over Troop Deployment|url=http://www.soaw.org/presente/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=298&Itemid=74|date=May 4, 2010|newspaper=¡Presente!}} ==Timeline== [[File:EPP Commandant.jpg|thumb|Alcides Oviedo Brítez, current EPP leader.|alt=]] {{main article|Insurgency in Paraguay}} By December 2013, the insurgency resulted in killing of at least 33 civilians and police officers, with an unknown number of killed EPP operatives. Two EPP operatives were killed in early April 2014, including the third in command in EPP; one Paraguayan soldier was also killed.{{cite web|url=http://www.insightcrime.org/news-briefs/paraguay-lauds-heavy-blow-to-epp-after-leaders-death |title=Paraguay Lauds Heavy Blow to EPP After Leader's Killing - InSight Crime | Organized Crime in the Americas |publisher=InSight Crime |date=2014-04-03 |accessdate=2014-05-19}} On August 27, 2016, the insurgents ambushed a mobile patrol of the Paraguayan army with a roadside bomb and automatic weapons, killing one officer and eight [[non-commissioned officer]]s. The guerrillas stole their [[M4 carbine|M-4 carbines]] and a light machine gun, along with 1,500 round of ammunitions. The incident took place near the village of Arroyito, east of [[Concepción, Paraguay|Concepción]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.com.py/edicion-impresa/notas/el-atentado-mas-cruel-del-epp-en-19-anos-1513026.html|title=El atentado más cruel del EPP en 19 años - Edicion Impresa - ABC Color|last=Color|first=ABC|language=es-ES|access-date=2016-08-28}} ==Political views== The EPP criticized the government of [[Fernando Lugo]], saying that he ignored the country's social problems and would not implement real [[land reform]].{{cite web|url=http://archivo.abc.com.py/2008-11-12/articulos/468967/anuncian-ocupaciones-violentas-en-nombre-del-ejercito-del-pueblo-paraguayo|title=Anuncian ocupaciones violentas en nombre del Ejército del Pueblo Paraguayo|work=ABC Digital|first=Freddy|last=Rojas|date=November 12, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120403091217/http://archivo.abc.com.py/2008-11-12/articulos/468967/anuncian-ocupaciones-violentas-en-nombre-del-ejercito-del-pueblo-paraguayo|archivedate=April 3, 2012|language=es}} In 2012, the EPP declared war on [[Federico Franco]]'s cabinet, describing the [[Impeachment of Fernando Lugo]] as a "white collar theft". The Paraguayan state describes the group as a terrorist organization. ==Links with other organizations== It is known that at least one key [[FARC]] leader, Orley Jurado Palomino, has gone to Paraguay to provide training, advice and operational leadership to the insurgent group.{{cite news|last=Escurra|first=Marta|title=Paraguayan guerrillas were trained by the FARC|url=http://infosurhoy.com/cocoon/saii/xhtml/en_GB/features/saii/features/main/2010/03/16/feature-01|newspaper=infosurhoy.com|date=March 16, 2010}} It is also unclear if the EPP has ties with some major Brazilian [[drug trafficking]] organizations, like the First Capital Command ([[Primeiro Comando da Capital]] – PCC) and Red Command or [[Comando Vermelho]] which are known to have a significant presence in northern Paraguay.{{cite news|last=Barrios|first=Hugo|title=Paraguay ups counter-narcotics effort on border with Brazil|url=http://infosurhoy.com/cocoon/saii/xhtml/en_GB/features/saii/features/main/2011/04/12/feature-03|newspaper=infosurhoy.com|date=April 12, 2010}} ===Kidnappings=== Along with armed raids, arson attacks and bombings, the group has also been accused of the kidnapping and murder of [[Cecilia Cubas]], the daughter of former [[President of Paraguay]] [[Raúl Cubas Grau]], as well as the abduction of Fidel Zavala, who was freed on January 17, 2010, after 94 days in captivity. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Paraguayan People's Army}} [[Category:Far-left politics]] [[Category:Organizations designated as terrorist in Latin America]] [[Category:Guerrilla organizations]] [[Category:Politics of Paraguay]] [[Category:Communist terrorism]] [[Category:Communist militant groups]] [[Category:Paramilitary organisations based in Paraguay]]

revision.text:
The '''Santini Collection''' is an archive of musical scores dating back to the 18th century, originally the collection of [[Fortunato Santini]], a Catholic priest born in a Roman orphanage in 1778. The archive contains autograph manuscripts by [[George Frideric Handel]] and [[Alessandro Scarlatti]], and in some cases preserved the only copies of these works for many years.
==External links== * [http://www.bach.gwdg.de/bio/santini_engl.html Biography of Fortunato Santini] * [http://www.dioezesanbibliothek-muenster.de/ the Diözesanbibliothek Münster], present home of the Santini collection
{{History-stub}} {{Music-stub}} [[Category:Music archives]] [[Category:Music organisations based in Germany]]

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Historical documents to [[:Category:Documents]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2016 May 1]].
revision.text:
'''Sheffield Local Studies Library''' (located in [[Sheffield]], [[South Yorkshire]], [[England]]) collects and preserves printed material relating to Sheffield and the surrounding area, and makes it available for study and research. The collection of over 30,000 volumes includes books, pamphlets, journals and reports on all aspects of the city's history and development and the lives of its people. Information on present day Sheffield includes statistics and special files on current issues. The Local Studies Library is a joint service with [[Sheffield Archives]]. They are part of the Sheffield Libraries Archives and Information Service delivered by [[Sheffield City Council]].The Local Studies Library is situated on the first floor of [[Sheffield Central Library]]. == Materials in the collections == === Newspapers === Newspapers have been published in Sheffield for over 200 years. The main titles are:
• ''[[Sheffield Register]]'' 1787-1794
• ''[[Sheffield Iris]]'' 1794-1839
• ''[[Sheffield & Rotherham Independent]]'' 1819-1938
• ''[[Sheffield Daily Telegraph]]'' 1855-1986
• ''[[Sheffield Star|Star]]'' 1873-
• ''[[Sheffield Telegraph]]'' 1989-
• ''[[Green 'Un]]'' (sports) 1907- === Directories === Sheffield street and trade directories from 1774 to 1974, also telephone directories from 1941. === Census returns === Microfilm copies of 1841 -1881 for Sheffield and parts of South Yorkshire and North Derbyshire. === Electoral registers === Registers of electors from 1841 to the present. === Ordnance Survey maps === Past editions of 6 inch and 25 inch Ordnance Survey maps and some earlier non-Ordnance Survey maps. Before the Second World War maps were produced as a ‘County Series’ at a scale of 6 inches to 1 mile (1:10,560) and 1:2,500 (25 inches to 1 mile). As Sheffield lies on the boundary of Yorkshire and Derbyshire and has extended its boundaries at various times, this sometimes leads to confusion. Yorkshire:
six-inch maps for this area were first published 1853-55.
1:2,500 maps were published in 1890 and revised in about 1905, 1923 and 1935. Derbyshire:
six-inch and 1:2,500 maps were first published in 1876 and revised in about 1898, 1923 and 1938. There are also town plans of Sheffield (these do not cover the whole of the present city):
1853 at 1:1056 scale
1890-93/1903 at 1:500 scale The National Grid survey began in 1949 and continues to the present day. Maps are available at 1:10,000, 1:2,500 and 1:1,250 scales. Coverage at the largest scales is restricted to Sheffield. === Illustrations === Over 60,000 illustrations, mainly black and white photographs, of people, places and events in the Sheffield area. === Ephemera === Includes many miscellaneous printed items such as publicity leaflets, posters, trade literature, playbills and property sale plans. === Sound recordings === Recordings of local interest include all types of music and the spoken word. There is also a collection of oral history recordings in which Sheffield people talk about their lives. === Film and video === An important collection of archive film shows scenes of life in Sheffield. == External links == * [http://www.sheffield.gov.uk/libraries Sheffield Libraries Archives and Information ] * [http://www.picturesheffield.com Picture Sheffield] * [http://www.sheffield.gov.uk Sheffield City Council] [[Category:Public libraries in South Yorkshire]] [[Category:Organisations based in Sheffield]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Sheffield|Local Studies]] [[Category:Culture in Sheffield]] [[Category:Documents]]

The '''talamaur''' is a [[vampire]] legend of the [[Banks Islands]], [[Vanuatu]], located in the [[Oceania|South Pacific]]. A talamaur was a type of vampire who controlled the ghost of a dead person, and could use it to drain the vitality from the living and the recently deceased.<ref>{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Superstitions, Folklore, and the Occult Sciences of the World|last1=Daniels|first1=Cora Linn|last2=Stevans|first2=C.M.|publisher=Minerva|pages=1364–1365|year=2003|ISBN=9781410209160}}</ref> Some people actually aspired to become talamaurs.<ref name="J._Gordon_Melton">{{cite book|first=J. Gordon|last=Melton|title=The Vampire Book|publisher=Visible Ink Press|year=2010|ISBN=9781578592814|pages=664–665}}</ref> The power of a talamaur could purportedly be gained by eating part of a corpse, thus gaining kinship with the soul of the deceased.<ref>{{cite book|last=Róheim|first=Géza|authorlink=Géza Róheim|title=Animism, Magic, and the Divine King|page=109|publisher=Taylor & Francis|ISBN=9780710073020|year=1972}}</ref>
A talamaur could be identified by exposure to the smoke of certain burning leaves, which would cause it to shout the names of the deceased person whose ghost it controlled and of the person whom it was afflicting.<ref>{{cite book|last=Summers|first=Montague|title=The Vampire, his Kith and Kin|year=1928|ISBN=9781605065663|publisher=Forgotten Books|page=227}}</ref> Injuries inflicted on the talamaur's ghostly form would appear on its living body; such bruising was used to identify a talamaur.<ref>{{cite book|title=Journal of the Royal Anthropological Institute of Great Britain and Ireland|volume=10|year=1881|page=285}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Vampires]]

I added how the Great Gama moved to Lahore in Pakistan post-partition and that he was from the British Raj
revision.text:
{{For|Stampede Wrestling villain and professional wrestler of the 1970s to 2000s|Gama Singh}} {{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox professional wrestler | name = Gama Pehalwan | image = Gama1916.jpg | birth_name = Ghulam Mohammad Baksh | birth_date = {{Birth date|1878|5|22|df=yes}} | death_date = {{Death date and age|1960|5|23|1878|5|22|df=yes}}Nidaay-e-Millat, Urdu Weekly Magazine 21–27 July 2016. Lahore | birth_place = [[Amritsar]], [[Punjab Province (British India)|Punjab]], [[British India]] | death_place = [[Lahore]], [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]], [[Pakistan]] | family = [[Imam Baksh Pahalwan]] (brother)
[[Kalsoom Nawaz Sharif]] (granddaughter) | names = Gama Pahalwan | height = {{convert|5|ft|7|in|cm|abbr=on}} | weight = {{convert|250|lb|kg|abbr=on}} | billed = | debut = | retired = }} '''Ghulam Mohammad Baksh''' (22 May 1878 – 23 May 1960), better known by the [[ring name]] '''The Great Gama''', was a [[Pehlwani|wrestler]] from the [[British Raj]] who then moved to [[Lahore]],[[Pakistan]] post-partition where he lived for the rest of his days.https://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2018/01/05/the-great-gama-and-lahore/{{cite news|last1=Banerjee|first1=Sarnath|authorlink1=Sarnath Banerjee|title=Gamanamah: The story of a strongman|url=http://www.timescrest.com/society/gamanamah-the-story-of-a-strongman-7471|accessdate=11 July 2017|work=The Times of India|date=10 March 2012|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20131014144633/http://www.timescrest.com/society/gamanamah-the-story-of-a-strongman-7471|archivedate=14 October 2013|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite book|last1=Hornbaker|first1=Tim|title=Legends of Pro Wrestling: 150 Years of Headlocks, Body Slams, and Piledrivers|date=2017|publisher=[[Skyhorse Publishing]]|isbn=9781613218754|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UuGLDAAAQBAJ|accessdate=11 July 2017}} Born in [[Amritsar]] village Jabbowal, then in the [[Punjab Province (British India)|Punjab Province]] of [[British India]], in 1878, he was awarded the Indian version of the [[World Heavyweight Championship (professional wrestling)|World Heavyweight Championship]] on 15 October 1910, and went on to defeat grappling champions across the world. Undefeated in a career spanning more than 52 years, he is considered one of the greatest wrestlers of all time.{{cite news|title=The culture and crisis of kushti|url=http://www.thehindu.com/opinion/columns/sainath/the-culture-and-crisis-of-kushti/article5297790.ece?homepage=true|newspaper=The Hindu|date=31 October 2013|accessdate=2 July 2016}} ==Early life== Ghulam Mohammad Baksh was born in the city of [[Amritsar]] village Jabbowal into an ethnic [[Kashmiri Muslim]] family of wrestlers in the [[Punjab region]] of [[British India]].{{cite book|last1=Lentz III|first1=Harris M.|title=Biographical Dictionary of Professional Wrestling|date=2003|publisher=[[McFarland & Company|McFarland]]|isbn=9780786417544|page=118|edition=2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JyiSCgAAQBAJ|accessdate=11 July 2017}}{{cite news |title=Here's The Story Of Gama 'The Undefeated' Pehalwan And How He Saved Hindus During 1947 Riots |url=https://www.indiatimes.com/news/india/here-s-the-story-of-gama-the-undefeated-pehalwan-and-how-he-saved-hindus-during-1947-riots-321745.html |work=[[India Times]] |date=16 May 2017}}{{cite news |title=The Great Gama and Lahore |url=https://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2018/01/05/the-great-gama-and-lahore/ |work=[[Pakistan Today]] |date=5 January 2018}} He came from a wrestling family which was known to produce world-class wrestlers.{{Citation needed|date= June 2018}} Gama had two wives: one in Pakistan and the other in [[Vadodara|Baroda]], [[Gujarat]], India.{{Citation needed|date= June 2018}} After the death of his father Muhammad Aziz Baksh when he was six, Gama was put under the care of his maternal grandfather Nun Pahalwan.{{Citation needed|date= June 2018}} Following his death, Gama was taken care of by his uncle Ida, another wrestler, who also began training Gama in wrestling.{{Citation needed|date= June 2018}} He was first noticed at the age of ten, in 1888, when he entered a [[Strongman (strength athlete)|strongman]] competition held in [[Jodhpur]], which included many gruelling exercises such as squats. The contest was attended by more than four hundred wrestlers and Gama was among the last fifteen, and was named winner by the Maharaja of Jodhpur due to his young age.{{cite book|last1=Sen|first1=Ronojoy|title=Nation at Play: A History of Sport in India|date=2015|publisher=[[Columbia University Press]]|isbn=9780231539937|page=167|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O5mACgAAQBAJ|accessdate=11 July 2017}} Gama was subsequently taken into training by the Maharaja of [[Datia]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.mensxp.com/special-features/today/26954-the-great-gama-story-of-the-greatest-pehelwan-to-ever-walk-on-indian-soil.html|title=The Great Gama: Story Of The Greatest 'Buffer' To Ever Walk On Indian Soil|last=Prasher|first=Shantanu|newspaper=www.mensxp.com|access-date=2017-01-14}} ==Training and diet== [[File:Squat, baithak, Hindu squat, possibly 'The Great Gamma'.png|thumb|Gama performing a baithak]] [[File:Dand, Dund, Hindu push-up.png|thumb|Gama performing a dand]] Gama's daily training consisted of grappling with forty of his fellow wrestlers in the court ([[Akhada]]). He used to do minimum five thousand Baithaks ([[Hindu Squats]]) and three thousand Dands ([[Hindu Pushups]]) in a day and even sometime more within 30 to 45 minutes each by wearing a doughnut-shaped wrestling apparatus called Hasli of 200 pounds.{{Cite web|url=http://legendarystrength.com/great-gama/|title=The Great Gama -|website=Legendary Strength|language=en-US|access-date=29 March 2016}} Gama's daily diet was # 2 gallons (10 liters) of milk, # one and a half pounds of crushed almond paste made into a tonic drink # fruit juice, # six desi chickens, # a half liter of ghee, # six pounds of butter, # three buckets of seasonal fruits, # two desi muttons and other ingredients to promote good digestion and recovery, although this high-protein and high-energy diet helped him accumulate muscle mass.{{Citation needed|date= June 2018}} ==Career== ===First encounter with Raheem Bakhsh Sultani Wala=== Fame came to Gama in 1895, at the age of 17 when he challenged then-Indian Wrestling Champion, middle-aged Raheem Bakhsh Sultani Wala, another ethnic Kashmiri wrestler from [[Gujranwala]], now in [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]], Pakistan.{{Citation needed|date= June 2018}} At about 7 feet tall, with a very impressive win-loss record, Raheem was expected to easily defeat the 5'7" Gama. Raheem's only drawback was his age as he was much older than Gama, and near the end of his career. The bout continued for hours and eventually ended in a draw.{{Citation needed|date= June 2018}} The contest with Raheem was the turning point in Gama's career. After that, he was looked upon as the next contender for the ''Indian Wrestling Championship''. In the first bout Gama remained defensive, but in the second bout, Gama went on the offensive. Despite severe bleeding from his nose and ears, he managed to deal out a great deal of damage to Raheem Bakhsh.{{Citation needed|date= June 2018}} By 1910, Gama had defeated all the prominent Indian wrestlers who faced him except the champion, Raheem Bakhsh Sultani Wala. At this time, he focused his attention on the rest of the world. Accompanied by his younger brother [[Imam Baksh Pahalwan|Imam Bakhsh]], Gama sailed to England to compete with the Western wrestlers but could not gain instant entry, because of his lower height.{{cite book|last=Alter|first=Joseph S.|title=The wrestler's body identity and ideology in North India|year=1992|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley|isbn=9780520912175|page=76|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EMu1xKEWBt4C}} ===Tournament in London=== In London, Gama issued a challenge that he could throw any three wrestlers in thirty minutes of any weight class. This announcement however was seen as a bluff by the wrestlers and their wrestling promoter R. B. Benjamin. For a long time no one came forward to accept the challenge. To break the ice, Gama presented another challenge to specific heavy weight wrestlers. He challenged [[Stanislaus Zbyszko]] and [[Frank Gotch]], either he would beat them or pay them the prize money and go home. The first professional wrestler to take his challenge was the American [[Ben Roller|Benjamin Roller]]. In the bout, Gama pinned Roller in 1 minute 40 seconds the first time, and in 9 minutes 10 seconds the other. On the second day, he defeated 12 wrestlers and thus gained entry to official tournament. ===Match with Stanislaus Zbyszko=== He was pitted against world champion [[Stanislaus Zbyszko]] and the date of bout was set as 10 September 1910. Zbyszko was now regarded among the premier wrestlers in the world; and he would then take on the mammoth challenge of India's feared Great Gama, an undefeated champion who had been unsuccessful in his attempts to lure Frank Gotch into a match. And so, on September 10, 1910, Zbyszko faced the Great Gama in the finals of the John Bull World Championships in London.{{Citation needed|date= June 2018}} The match was £250 in prize money and the John Bull Belt. Within a minute, Zbyszko was taken down and remained in that position for the remaining 2 hours and 35 minutes of the match. There were a few brief moments when Zbyszko would get up, but he just ended back down in his previous position. Crafting a defensive strategy of hugging the mat in order to nullify Great Gama’s greatest strengths, Zbyszko wrestled the Indian legend to a draw after nearly three hours of grappling, though Zbyszko’s lack of tenacity angered many of the fans in attendance. {{Citation needed|date= June 2018}} The two men were set to face each other again but Zbyszko didn't show up and Gama was announced victor.
===Bouts against American and European champions=== During this tour Gama defeated some of the most respected grapplers in the world, "Doc" [[Benjamin Roller]] of the United States, Maurice Deriaz of Switzerland, Johann Lemm (the European Champion) of Switzerland, and [[Jesse Peterson]] (World Champion) from Sweden. In the match against Roller, Gama threw "Doc" 13 times in the 15-minute match.{{Citation needed|date= June 2018}} Gama now issued a challenge to the rest of those who laid claim to the World Champion's Title, including Japanese [[Judo]] champion [[Taro Miyake]], [[George Hackenschmidt]] of Russia and [[Frank Gotch]] of the United States – each declined his invitation to enter the ring to face him. At one point, to face some type of competition, Gama offered to fight twenty English wrestlers, one after another. He announced that he would defeat all of them or pay out prize money, but still no one would take up his challenge.{{Citation needed|date= June 2018}} ===Final encounter with Raheem Bakhsh Sultani Wala=== Shortly after his return from England, Gama faced Raheem Bakhsh Sultani Wala in [[Allahabad]]. This bout eventually ended the long struggle between the two pillars of Indian wrestling of that time in favour of Gama and he won the title of ''Rustam-e-Hind'' or Champion of India. Later in his life when asked about who was his strongest opponent, Gama replied, "Raheem Bakhsh Sultani Wala".{{Citation needed|date= June 2018}} ===Rematch with Zbyszko=== After beating Raheem Bakhsh Sultani Wala, Gama faced Pandit Biddu{{citation needed|date=April 2012}}, who was one of the best wrestlers in [[India]] of that time (1916), and beat him. In 1922, during a visit to India, the [[Prince of Wales]] presented Gama with a silver [[Ceremonial mace|mace]]. Gama did not have any opponents until 1927, when it was announced that Gama and Zbyszko would face each other again. They met in [[Patiala]] in January 1928.{{cite news|title=World Wrestling Championship: Indian's Victory Over Pole|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/singfreepressb19280214-1.2.15|publisher=The Singapore Free Press and Mercantile Advertise|accessdate=9 May 2017|page=4|date=14 February 1928}} Entering the bout, Zbyszko "showed a strong build of body and muscle" and Gama, it was reported "looked thinner usual". However, he managed to overpower the former easily and won the bout inside a minute, winning the Indian version of the [[World Wrestling Championship]]. Following the bout, Zbyszko praised him calling him a "tiger".{{cite news|title=World Wrestling Championship: Gama Beats Zbyszko|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/singfreepressb19280303-1.2.36|accessdate=9 May 2017|work=The Singapore Free Press and Mercantile Advertiser|date=3 March 1928|page=6}}
At forty-eight years old he was now known as the "Great wrestler" of India. ===Fight with Balram Heeraman Singh Yadav=== After defeating Zbyszko, Gama beat Jesse Petersen in February 1929. The bout lasted only one and a half minutes. This was the last bout that Gama fought during his career.{{citation needed|date=May 2018}} In the 1940s he was invited by the Nizam of Hyderabad and defeated all his fighters. The Nizam then sent him to face the wrestler Balram Heeraman Singh Yadav, who was never defeated in his life. The fight was very long. Gama was unable to defeat Heeraman and eventually neither wrestler won. Heeraman was one of the toughest wrestlers for Gama to face.{{Citation needed|date= June 2018}} After the independence and [[Partition of India|partition of India]] in 1947, Gama moved to [[Pakistan]]. During the Hindu-Muslim riots that broke out at the time of partition, the [[Muslim]] Gama saved hundreds of [[Hindus]] from mobs in [[Lahore]]. Although Gama did not retire until 1952, he failed to find any other opponents. After his retirement, he trained his nephew Bholu Pahalwan, who held the Pakistani wrestling championship for almost 20 years.{{Citation needed|date= June 2018}} ==Death== The Great Gama died in [[Lahore]], [[Pakistan]] on 23 May 1960 after a period of illness. He was given land by the government but he still struggled to pay for treatment for his heart and [[asthma]]. Therefore, [[Ghanshyam Das Birla|G. D. Birla]], an Indian industrialist and wrestling fan, donated Rs. 2,000 and a monthly pension of Rs. 300, and the [[Government of Pakistan]] also increased the pension to Gama and supported his medical expenses until his death. Today, a doughnut-shaped exercise disc called Hasli weighing 95 kg, used by him for squats, is housed at the [[National Institute of Sports]] (NIS) Museum at [[Patiala, India]].[http://www.tribuneindia.com/2001/20011124/windows/main5.htm A rare museum] ''[[The Tribune (Chandigarh)|The Tribune]]'', Published 24 November 2001, Retrieved 2 July 2016 ==Other== [[Bruce Lee]] was an avid follower of Gama's training routine. Lee read articles about Gama and how he employed his exercises to build his legendary strength for wrestling, and Lee quickly incorporated them into his own routine. The training routines Lee used included "[[Push-up|the cat stretch]]", "the squat" (known as "baithak"), and also known as the "deep-knee bend."Little, John, ''Bruce Lee – The Art of Expressing The Human Body'' (Tuttle Publishing, 1998), p. 58 ==Championships and accomplishments== *'''[[George Tragos/Lou Thesz Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame]]''' ** Class of 2007{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.com/Slam/Wrestling/2007/07/14/4339684.html|title=Emotions run high at Tragos/Thesz induction|last=Johnson|first=Steve|website=Slam! Wrestling|publisher=[[Canadian Online Explorer]]|date=July 14, 2007|accessdate=November 6, 2018}} *'''[[Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame and Museum]]''' ** Class of 2015{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/2014/11/26/22096551.html|title=Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame Class of 2015 announced|last=Oliver|first=Greg|date=26 November 2014|accessdate=2 July 2016|work=Slam! Sports|publisher=[[Canadian Online Explorer]]}} == References == ==External links== *[http://ejmas.com/jalt/jaltart_noble_0502.htm The Lion of the Punjab – Gama in England, 1910 By Graham Noble] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061017210037/http://bod.sagepub.com/cgi/content/abstract/6/2/45 Subaltern Bodies and Nationalist Physiques: Gama the Great and the Heroics of Indian Wrestling by Joseph Alter, Department of Anthropology at the University of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA] {{Pride of Performance for Sports}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Great Gama, The}} [[Category:1878 births]] [[Category:1960 deaths]] [[Category:Pakistani people of Kashmiri descent]] [[Category:People from Datia]] [[Category:Pakistani professional wrestlers]] [[Category:Pakistani bodybuilders]] [[Category:Recipients of the Pride of Performance]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Amritsar]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Lahore]] [[Category:Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame and Museum]] [[Category:Sport wrestlers from Punjab, Pakistan]]

'''The Infatuation''' (formerly known as '''Immaculate Infatuation''') is an American [[New York City|New York]]-based restaurant recommendation website and messaging service, created by former music industry executives [[Chris Stang]] and [[Andrew Steinthal]] in 2009. They are most known for publishing restaurant reviews and guides, and as creators of the hashtag #EEEEEATS.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/two-execs-quit-their-jobs-to-start-the-infatuation-2015-5|title=Why two music industry execs quit their jobs to start a wildly popular food site|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-03-06}}</ref>
They have developed an Android and iPhone app<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/travel-apps-gadgets-2017-4#5-lola-is-like-having-a-travel-agent-in-your-pocket-5|title=16 of the coolest apps and gadgets you should use the next time you travel|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-03-06}}</ref>, and operate an SMS-based restaurant recommendation service called Text Rex<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://observer.com/2016/03/this-text-service-offers-personalized-restaurant-recommendations/|title=This Text Service Offers Personalized Restaurant Recommendations|date=2016-03-08|work=Observer|access-date=2018-03-06|language=en-US}}</ref>. In 2017 they launched their food and music festival brand EEEEEATSCON.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeout.com/los-angeles/blog/the-infatuation-launches-eeeeeatscon-possibly-the-coolest-food-fest-yet-031517|title=The Infatuation launches EEEEEATSCON, possibly the coolest food fest yet|work=Time Out Los Angeles|access-date=2018-03-06|language=en}}</ref>
On March 5, 2018, the company acquired the [[Zagat]] rating company from [[Google]] for an undisclosed amount.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/05/business/dealbook/zagat-google-infatuation.html|title=Google to Sell Zagat to The Infatuation, an Upstart Review Site|last=Merced|first=Michael J. de la|date=2018-03-05|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-03-06|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
== History == ''Immaculate Infatuation'' was established in 2009 by Stang and Steinthal with the aim of providing honest restaurant reviews without accepting invitations from restaurants or announcing their presence to a wait staff.<ref name=":0" /> They later shortened the company name to The Infatuation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://insights.newscred.com/infatuationcommunity-food-lovers/|title=How The Infatuation Built a Passionate Community of Millions of Food Lovers|date=2017-05-03|work=Insights|access-date=2018-03-06|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Funding === On June 1, 2014, ''The Infatuation'' raised $1 million from a first round of seed funding from four investors, including Griffen Avenue Ventures and Empire Angels.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/funding_round/the-infatuation-seed--220c1b1c#section-locked-marketplace|title=Seed Round - The Infatuation - 2014-06-01 {{!}} Crunchbase|website=Crunchbase|language=en|access-date=2018-03-06}}</ref>
On September 25, ''The Infatuation'' raised $2.5 million from a second round of seed funding from Maywic Select Investments.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/funding_round/the-infatuation-seed--738de8c7#section-locked-marketplace|title=Seed Round - The Infatuation - 2016-09-25 {{!}} Crunchbase|website=Crunchbase|language=en|access-date=2018-03-06}}</ref>
=== Zagat Acquisition === On March 5, 2018, ''The Infatuation'' acquired Zagat's brand and assets from Google. They did not disclose the amount.<ref name=":2" /> They will reportedly operate as two distinct brands, with ''The Infatuation'' retaining its editorial-first focus and Zagat will expand user surveys and develop a new tech-driven platform.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-03-05/restaurant-review-platform-the-infatuation-buys-zagat|title=Restaurant Review Platform The Infatuation Buys Zagat|date=2018-03-05|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2018-03-06|language=en}}</ref>
== #EEEEEATS == ''In 2012, The Infatuation'' started to use #EEEEEATS as a way to tag their food photos on [[Instagram]]. The 5 E's are explained as a way to make "[what we do] feel fun" and "[to not] take things too seriously."<ref name=":0" /> The hashtag was quickly adopted by the food community and now has grown to over 10 million tags.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/explore/tags/eeeeeats/?hl=en|title=#eeeeeats • Instagram photos and videos|website=www.instagram.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-06}}</ref> The company also operates 22 different Instagram handles including the main @infatuation account, one for each of their operating cities, and food-specific accounts like @pizza, @avocadotoast, and @burger.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/how-food-blog-the-infatuation-uses-instagram-2017-5|title=How Instagram helped the founders of The Infatuation quit their jobs and work full-time on food reviews|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-03-06}}</ref>
== Underfinger == In May 2014, ''The Infatuation'' published a satirical review of a faux restaurant by the name of ''Underfinger'', featuring "farm to finger" foods like seahorse sashimi and charcuterie gloves. The fictional restaurant was later brought to life in a pop-up event hosted by Brooklyn restaurant ''Do or Dine''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://observer.com/2014/06/underfinger-the-real-fake-restaurant-thats-confusing-us-all/|title=Underfinger, the Real Fake Restaurant That’s Confusing Us All|date=2014-06-03|work=Observer|access-date=2018-03-06|language=en-US}}</ref> A short-form documentary was created from the pop-up and later earned the company a James Beard Foundation Journalism Award nomination in the Humor category.<ref name=":0" />
== EEEEEATSCON == On May 20, 2017, ''The Infatuation'' organized and hosted their inaugural food and music festival EEEEEATSCON at the [[Santa Monica Airport|Barker Hangar]] in [[Santa Monica, California|Santa Monica, CA]].<ref name=":1" /> The event was described as a "Music Festival Catered Towards Food" and included restaurant vendors with speaking engagements featuring talent manager [[Shep Gordon]] and baker [[Nancy Silverton]], and live music performances by rapper [[Lizzo]] and electronic music duo [[The Knocks]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/lifestyle/7809431/the-infatuation-food-fest-music-festival-santa-monica-eeeeeatscon|title=The Infatuation's Debut EEEEEATSCON Is a 'Music Festival Catered Towards Food'|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-03-06}}</ref>
EEEEEATSCON returned to the Barker Hangar on May 19, 2018 with an appearance by Lilia's [[Missy_Robbins|Missy Robbins]] and musical performances by The Spencer Lee Band and [[Gavin Turek]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.welikela.com/event/eeeeeatscon-returns-barker-hangar-may-19-2018/|title=EEEEEATSCON Returns to Barker Hangar|access-date=2018-03-06|language=en-US}}</ref>. The third event in the series will be held on October 6, 2018 at [[Forest Hills Stadium]] in the [[New York City]] borough of [[Queens]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Woodward |first1=Danielle |title=NYC's First "EEEEEATSCON" Food Fest Comes To Forest Hills Stadium |url=https://patch.com/new-york/foresthills/nycs-first-eeeeeatscon-food-fest-comes-forest-hills-stadium |website=Patch |publisher=Patch |accessdate=2018-07-30}}</ref>
== See Also == * [[Zagat]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox book | | name = The World Atlas of Wine | image = The World Atlas of Wine, 7th Edition cover.jpg | caption = Seventh edition cover | author = [[Hugh Johnson (wine)|Hugh Johnson]]
[[Jancis Robinson]] | cover_artist = | country = United Kingdom | language = English | genre = [[Wine]] [[atlas]] | publisher = [[Mitchell Beazley]] | release_date = October 2013 (seventh edition) | media_type = Print ([[hardcover]]), ebook ([[iBooks Author]]) | pages = 400 | isbn = 978-1-84533-689-9 | oclc= 213401236 }} '''''The World Atlas of Wine''''' by [[Hugh Johnson (wine)|Hugh Johnson]] and (since 2003) [[Jancis Robinson]], [[Master of Wine|MW]], is an [[atlas]] and reference work on the world of [[wine]], published by [[Mitchell Beazley]]. It pioneered the use of wine-specific [[cartography]] to give wine a sense of place, and has since the first edition published in 1971 sold 4 million copies in 14 languages.{{Cite web |last= Robinson |first= Jancis, jancisrobinson.com |url= http://www.jancisrobinson.com/articles/books |title= Books |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080808143754/http://jancisrobinson.com/articles/books |archivedate= 2008-08-08 |df= }} Considered among the most significant wine publications to date, and it remains one of the most popular books on wine, with the most recent seventh edition published in October 2013.{{cite web| last = Rosen |first= Maggie, ''Decanter.com''| title = Hugh Johnson, Jancis Robinson release new 'World Atlas of Wine' | url = http://www.decanter.com/news/148005.html| date= October 5, 2007 }} ==Origin== {{Essay-like|date=July 2008}} Prior to its publication in 1971, no work of wine literature contained high quality, wine-specific cartography. Some single-subject wine literature contained simple line-drawn maps, but not detailed, colour cartography with precise boundaries, and no book attempting to cover the world of wine had maps for every country. It was therefore not possible to open a bottle, open a book, and see precisely where the wine came from. This sense of place for wine is taken for granted today, but in 1971 it was revolutionary, and Johnson’s timing was impeccable. Until the [[World War II]], wine was the preserve of the upper classes in western Europe, and virtually non-existent in the U.S. due to Prohibition, but servicemen returning home from the European theatre brought with them the newly acquired habit of wine drinking. With the emergence of mass tourism in the 1950s and the greater spending power of the 1960s, a whole new generation visited France, Italy and Spain, bringing back the continental culture of wine. America's taste for wine also began to develop in the early 1960s. The majority of these new wine drinkers were young, well-traveled, and relatively affluent and, as the [[Baby boom|Baby Boom]] generation came of age, so the ranks of wine drinkers increased. Never before, and never since, have there been so many new wine consumers without any knowledge of the wines they were encountering, and in 1971 ''The World Atlas of Wine'' was uniquely placed to satisfy that demand. With mass tourism on the increase throughout the 1970s, the demand for ''The World Atlas of Wine'' continued to grow, as there was no real competition until 1988, when ''The Sotheby's World Wine Encyclopedia'' (now ''[[The Sotheby's Wine Encyclopedia]]'') was published. The [[Institut National des Appellations d'Origine]], a French governmental organisation that avoids comment on commercial ventures, was moved to describe ''The World Atlas of Wine'' upon publication as "a major landmark in the literature of wine".{{cite web |url=http://www.winebookreview.com/wine-book-review-johnson-robinson-the-world-atlas-of-wine/ |title=Wine Book Review - The World Atlas of Wine - Hugh Johnson, Jancis Robinson |work=WineBookReview.com |accessdate=24 June 2010 }}[http://www.intowine.com/shop/0332-4.html IntoWine: The World Atlas of Wine]{{Cite web|last=Robinson |first=Jancis, jancisrobinson.com |url=http://www.jancisrobinson.com/articles/20070106_1 |title=Who on earth are we? |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080214050732/http://www.jancisrobinson.com/articles/20070106_1 |archivedate=February 14, 2008 }} The distinctive maps for the First Edition of the Atlas were drawn by Fairey Surveys Ltd Cartographic office in Maidenhead, UK. Although many maps have been added in later editions many of the original maps of the classic wine areas are still used in the current edition. ==iPad Edition== The seventh edition was simultaneously released as hardcover print book and ebook for the iPad using Apple's [[iBooks Author]] format (referred to as 'Made for iBooks' in [[iBooks]]). In December 2013 it was announced that the ebook was a finalist for a Digital Book Award.Digital Book World website (Jan 2014) http://conference.digitalbookworld.com/ehome/70445/digital%20book%20awards/?& The ebook was also featured in the Best of 2013 promotion in iBooks. ==Editions== * First edition was printed in 1971{{cite book|author=Johnson, Hugh|title=World Atlas of wine.|publisher= Simon & Schuster|year=1971|isbn=0-671-21109-9}} * Second in 1977{{cite book|author=Johnson, Hugh|title=World Atlas of wine.|publisher=London : Mitchell Beazley|year=1977|edition=2nd|pages=288|isbn=0-85533-002-3}} * Third in 1985 {{cite book|author=Johnson, Hugh|title=The world atlas of wine : a complete guide to the wines and spirits of the world|publisher=London : Mitchell Beazley|year=1985 (1988 printing)|edition=3rd ed., completely rev. and extended.|pages=320|isbn=0-85533-562-9}} * Fourth in 1994 {{cite book|author=Johnson, Hugh|title=World Atlas of wine.|publisher=London : Mitchell Beazley|year=1994|edition=4th ed., completely rev.|pages=320|isbn=1-85732-268-1}} * Fifth in 2001 {{cite book|author=Johnson, Hugh|title=World Atlas of wine.|publisher=London : Mitchell Beazley|year=2001|edition=5th|pages=352|isbn=1-84000-332-4}} * Sixth in 2007{{cite book|author=Hugh Johnson, Jancis Robinson|title=World Atlas of wine.|publisher=London : Mitchell Beazley|year=2007|edition=6th|pages=400|isbn=978-1-84533-301-0}} * Seventh in 2013{{cite book|author=Hugh Johnson, Jancis Robinson|title=World Atlas of wine.|publisher=London : Mitchell Beazley|year=2013|edition=7h|pages=400|isbn=978-1-84533-689-9}} ==References== {{refbegin}} * [http://worldatlasofwine.com ''The World Atlas of Wine'' website] Octopus Publishing Group * [http://worldatlasofwine.com/ipad-edition ''World Atlas of Wine iPad Edition'' website] Octopus Publishing Group * [http://www.faireysurveys.co.uk "Fairey Surveys" website] {{refend}} ;Footnotes {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:World Atlas Of Wine}} [[Category:1971 books]] [[Category:Atlases]] [[Category:Books about wine]]

{{Infobox person |name = W. Richard West Jr. |image = WRichardWestJr.jpg |birth_name = Walter Richard West Jr. |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1943|01|06}} |birth_place = |death_date = |occupation = |alma_mater = |spouse = Mary Beth Braden |children = 2 }} '''Walter Richard "Rick" West Jr.''' (born January 6, 1943) is the president and CEO of the [[Autry National Center]] in Los Angeles.<ref>http://www.jewishjournal.com/cover_story/article/autry_president_w._richard_west_jr._embodies_american_complexity</ref> He was the founding director of the [[Smithsonian]] [[National Museum of the American Indian]],<ref name=ford>[http://www.fordfound.org/about/bios/w_west "Biography: W. Richard West Jr." ''Ford Foundation''] (Retrieved 16 Jan 09)</ref> retiring from the position in 2007. He is also a citizen of the [[Cheyenne and Arapaho Tribes]] in [[Oklahoma]] and a [[Council of Forty-four|Peace Chief]]<ref>Belcher, Steve. "'Cheyene Justice' exhibit on display." ''Clinton Daily News.'' 18 May 2005.</ref> of the [[Southern Cheyenne]].<ref name=doi>"W. Richard West." ''Department of the Interior'' [http://www.doi.gov/news/west.htm] (retrieved 16 Jan 09)</ref> His professional life has been devoted to serving the [[Native Americans in the United States|American Indian]] community on cultural, artistic, educational, legal and governmental issues.<ref name=ford/><ref name=doi/>
==Background== Born in [[San Bernardino, California]], West grew up in a log cabin in [[Muskogee, Oklahoma]].<ref name=stanford>[http://www.stanfordalumni.org/news/magazine/1998/marapr/articles/west.html "A Warrior in Washington" ''Stanford Magazine''] (Retrieved 17 Jun 12)</ref> He is the son of Maribelle McCrea West, a Baptist minister's daughter of Scottish-American background and the late [[Dick West|Walter Richard West Sr.]] (1912–1996).<ref name="stanford"/> His father, "Dick" West, was a well-respected Cheyenne painter, who chaired the art department at [[Bacone College]].<ref>Jones, Ruthe Blalock. "West, Walter Richard Sr. (1912–1996)." [http://digital.library.okstate.edu/encyclopedia/entries/W/WE015.html Oklahoma Historical Society's Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History & Culture] (retrieved 16 Jan 09)</ref>
Richard West earned a bachelor of arts degree in American History, graduating ''[[magna cum laude]]'' in 1965 and graduated [[Phi Beta Kappa]] from the [[University of Redlands]] in California.<ref name=ford/> He also received a master's degree in American History from [[Harvard University]] in 1968. West graduated from [[Stanford Law School]] with a doctor of jurisprudence degree in 1971, where he also was the recipient of the Hilmer Oehlmann Jr. Prize for excellence in legal writing and served as an editor and note editor of the ''[[Stanford Law Review]]''.<ref name=ford/>
==Professional career== West was a partner in the [[Washington, D.C.]], office of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, and, subsequently, in the Indian-owned [[Albuquerque]] law firm of [[Gover, Stetson, Williams & West, P.C.]]<ref name=ford/> During his law career, West served as both a general counsel and special counsel to a wide range of tribes and non-tribal organizations, before tribal, state, and federal and tribal courts. He also represented clients before several executive departments of the [[U.S. Federal Government]] and the [[U.S. Congress|Congress]].<ref name=doi/>
West was the subject of controversy after the ''[[Washington Post]]'' exposed lavish travel expenses and a gala farewell celebration during his tenure in the Smithsonian.<ref>Grimaldi, James V. [http://voices.washingtonpost.com/washingtonpostinvestigations/2008/10/by_james_v_grimaldi_washington.html "'Lavish' Spending Not Found Elsewhere At Smithsonian."] ''Washington Post.'' 30 Oct 2008 (Retrieved 16 Jan 09)</ref> This is part of a general crackdown on Smithsonian expenses by the [[General Accounting Office]]. West has stated that the travel was for museum business and approved by supervisors. After conducting an investigation at the request of the United States Congress, the Smithsonian Institution's inspector general found that West "should have exercised better judgment." West has agreed to reimburse the Smithsonian $9,700.<ref>Former Director to pay Smithsonian, New York Times, Oct. 30, 2008</ref> The Smithsonian Office of the Inspector General, A. Sprightley Ryan, published a 42-page report on October 28, 2008 responding to media reports and congressional requests.<ref>Office of the Inspector General Response to Congressional Requests, W. Richard West, Travel and Expense - Full Report [http://www.si.edu/oig/AuditReports/WRW_TravelReview.pdf]</ref>
From 2007 to 2010, West served as the Vice President of the [[International Council of Museums]].<ref>http://www.sitesofconscience.org/leaders/w-richard-west/ Accessed 5/15/14.</ref> In 2011, he was appointed as the Interim Director for the Textile Museum in Washington D.C.<ref>http://artdaily.com/news/54082/Textile-Museum-in-Washington-appoints-W--Richard-West--Jr--as-Interim-Director Accessed 5/15/14.</ref> Since 2011, he has served on the Board of Directors of the Native Arts and Cultures Foundation.<ref>http://www.nativeartsandcultures.org/about-foundation/our-board {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090424033318/http://nativeartsandcultures.org/about-foundation/our-board |date=2009-04-24 }} NACF Board of Directors. Accessed 5/14/14.</ref> In 2012, the [[Association of Tribal Archives, Libraries, & Museums]] (ATALM) honored West with a Guardians of Culture and Lifeways International Award<ref>http://theonefeather.com/2012/05/nacf-board-members-to-be-honored/ Cherokee One Feather, "NACF Board Members to Be Honored," (5/1/12). Accessed 5/14/15.</ref> and the Autry National Center designated West as the new President and CEO.<ref>http://articles.latimes.com/2013/apr/27/entertainment/la-et-cm-autry-director-richard-west-20130428 Los Angeles Times. Accessed 5/15/14.</ref>
==Personal life== West married Mary Beth Braden, a fellow Stanford graduate. She is the professor of political science at the [[National Defense University]], [[Industrial College of the Armed Forces]]. Together they have two adult children, Amy and Ben.<ref name=doi/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{cite web|url=http://www.nmai.si.edu/press/releases/09-03-04_rick_west_biography.pdf |title=W. Richard West Jr. biography |accessdate=September 25, 2013 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080307005420/http://www.nmai.si.edu/press/releases/09-03-04_rick_west_biography.pdf |archivedate=March 7, 2008 }} from National Museum of the American Indian site *[http://books.nap.edu/readingroom/books/techgap/media/wwest.html W. Richard West Jr. interview]. Audio recording. *[http://cdm16028.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15324coll10/id/95115/rec/1 Native paths: American Indian art from the collection of Charles and Valerie Diker], an exhibition catalog from The Metropolitan Museum of Art (fully available online as PDF), which contains an essay by W. Richard West Jr.
{{Authority control}}

{{more references|date=August 2014}} [[File:Jugoslovenska kinoteka.jpg|thumb|Yugoslav Film Archives headquarters at St. Uzun Mirkova, Belgrade, Serbia]] The '''Yugoslav Film Archive''' ({{lang-sr|Југословенска кинотека / Jugoslovenska kinoteka}}) is a [[Cinematheque|film archive]] located in [[Belgrade]], now in [[Serbia]]. It is a founding member of the [[International Federation of Film Archives]] and was the national film library of the [[former Yugoslavia]] and currently of the [[Republic of Serbia]].{{fact|date=August 2014}} It was founded in 1949.
The film collection contains over 95 thousand film prints of various national productions, of all genres, silent and sound, black & white and color, both nitrate and acetate.{{fact|date=August 2014}} Around 85% of the entire film collection consists of foreign film material, including some previously considered lost, which makes the archive particularly interesting for film archivists and researchers from all over the world.
The Yugoslav Film Fund saved the most important archive material and documentaries related to the territory of former Yugoslavia, starting from the oldest extant film in the country ''Coronation of King Peter the First'' from 1904 until its restoration in 1992.{{fact|date=August 2014}} The collection of [[Yugoslav film]]s includes more than 90% of production since the [[Second World War]]. Most of the films have a copy protection (two copies per title). The film collection is constantly increasing deposit of films made and the placed in the country, sharing with other film archives, and through purchase and gifts from individuals and institutions.
The archival photographic collection contains approximately 250,000 identified (and as much unprocessed) images from local or foreign film productions, portraits of film workers and other participants in the film industry.{{fact|date=August 2014}} Collection of documents and written film material contains all types of documents, letters, contracts, original scripts and other material relevant to the history and study of national cinema.
The archival collection contains posters of films (domestic and foreign productions) and movie festivals. The Archive has processed about 15,000 posters and about 200,000 of unidentified and untreated material. Priority task is the protection of posters related to domestic films.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kinoteka.org.yu/eng1.htm|title=Yugoslav Film Archive|publisher=Yugoslav Film Archive|accessdate=2009-01-23}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of film archives]]
